Title: Topcon Photovoltaic Cell
Research Focus: Effect of Water Vapor and Humidity on Photovoltaic Cell Performance
Key Findings: Poor weathering and high humidity have a negative impact on photovoltaic cells and panels' performance. Haze has a major impact on photovoltaic (PV) power generation. Moisture intrusion is at the center of most degradation mechanisms that lead to PV module power degradation.

Title: N/A
Research Focus: Passivating contacts on silicon solar cells
Key Findings: A 10x10 cm² cell yielded an efficiency of 22.9%.

Title: N/A
Key Findings: TOPCon-concepts are found to remain economically competitive against bifacial PERC in terms of levelized cost of electricity (LCOE), if a minimum absolute gain in cell efficiency Δ η > 0.55% for most-conservative and Δ η > 0.40% for most-progressive scenarios respectively can be maintained.

Title: Fa-Jun Ma
Research Focus: Silicon solar cells, Space applications, 1 MeV electron irradiation, Numerical simulation, PERC, TOPCon
Key Findings: When utilizing substrates with high doping levels, both PERC and TOPCon cells exhibit nearly identical beginning-of-life (BOL) and end-of-life (EOL) performance. However, with lower substrate doping concentrations, both technologies show improved BOL efficiency. Notably, this enhanced BOL efficiency does not translate into superior EOL efficiency. This distinction in EOL efficiency can be attributed to two primary factors triggered by radiation exposure. Firstly, the emergence of defects leads to a reduction in open-circuit voltage. Secondly, dopant compensation contributes to an increase in series resistance.

Title: N/A
Research Focus: Silicon solar cells with passivating contacts
Key Findings: Recombination induced loss mechanisms, Shockley-Read-Hall recombination in the c-Si bulk as a source of FF reduction in case of high resistivity Si, cells made of high resistivity 1Ω cm n-type Si are very sensitive to even a weak lifetime limitation in the c-Si bulk, achieved conﬁrmed eﬃciency values of 25.7%

Title: Reassessment of the Limiting Efﬁciency for Crystalline Silicon Solar Cells
Key Findings: Maximum theoretical efficiency of 29.43% for a 110-μm-thick solar cell made of undoped silicon.

Title: Optimization strategies for metallization in n-type crystalline silicon TOPCon solar cells: Pathways to elevated fill factor and enhanced efficiency
Key Findings: A squeegee speed of 170 mm/s substantially boosts solar cell performance, evidenced by a current density (Jsc) of 38.96 mA/cm2, open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 684.29 mV, fill factor (FF) of 78.77 %, and a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 21.00 %. Further, dark I – V measurements confirmed a shunt resistance (Rsh) of 6.25 × 106 Ω and a reduced series resistance (Rs) of 6.48 Ω , underscoring the significance of precise metallization in reducing resistive losses and enhancing efficiency.

Research Focus: Crystalline Silicon (c-Si)-Based Tunnel Oxide Passivated Contact (TOPCon) Solar Cells
Key Findings: A state-of-the-art n-type c-Si-based TOPCon solar cell featuring a passivated rear contact was experimentally analyzed, and the highest PCE record of ~25.7% was achieved. It has a high ﬁll factor (FF) of ~83.3%.

Key Findings: TOPCon structure enables high conversion efﬁciency and highFF. Boron-doped passivated rear contact (p-TOPCon) shows reduced SRH recombination and improved FF potential compared to standard p-PRC cells.

Title: N/A
Research Focus: Tunnel Oxide Passivated Contact solar cells
Key Findings: TOPCon solar cells are gaining more interests due to possessing various advantages such as availability of raw material, easy process sequence, high efficiency potential.

Title: N/A
Research Focus: High-Performance TiO 2 -Based Electron-Selective Contacts for Crystalline Silicon Solar Cells
Key Findings: Ultra-high PCE of 25.1% and 25.6%, respectively, has been achieved in silicon heterojunction (SHJ) and silicon heterojunction inter-digitated back-contact (SHJ-IBC) cells based on the intrinsic a-Si:H/doped a-Si:H CSC. A double-heterojunction silicon solar cell with an efficiency of 12.9% has been fabricated via the implementation of a hole-blocking TiO 2 layer.

Title: N/A
Key Findings: The quality of passivation of the tunnel oxide layer clearly depends on the bond of SiO in the tunnel oxide layer, which is affected by the subsequent annealing and the tunnel oxide layer was formed in the suboxide region (SiO, Si2O, Si2O3). To control the surface morphology, annealing profile, and acceleration rate, an oxide tunnel junction structure with a passivation characteristic of 700 mV or more (Voc) on a p-type wafer could achieve.

Title: Hafnium oxide
Key Findings: 21.3% increase in charge carrier lifetime through optimized HfO2 layers, potentially boosting efficiency by 25%.

Title: N/A
Key Findings: The passivated emitter and rear cell (PERC) technology and the use of gallium as the dominant p-type dopant have vastly exceeded the expected trends, while the adoption of silicon heterojunction cells and shifting to n-type wafers has not occurred as quickly as expected.

Title: Xinyuan Wu
Key Findings: Laser-assisted firing techniques such as laser-enhanced contact optimization (LECO) significantly improve the reliability of TOPCon solar cells due to compatibility with screen printing pastes that have low or zero Al concentration for the TOPCon front. This approach enables using more cost-effective materials for TOPCon modules, thereby reducing the overall cost of solar electricity.

Title: TOPCon
Research Focus: PERC, TOPCon, and SHJ solar cells
Key Findings: TOPCon structure with a high passivation performance and good optical performance is more suitable for bifacial solar cell and the highest theoretical limiting efficiency with metal shading on the n-type Si wafer (ηb,e,h,m,max) can be achieved to 27.62%.

Title: Yuguo Tao
Research Focus: n-type Si solar cells with 21.2% efﬁciency
Key Findings: The best example of the potential of passivated contact is the heterojunction Si cell with intrinsic thin amorphous layer (HIT) solar cell. HIT cells have produced outstanding cell Voc of 750 mV and cell efﬁciency exceeding 25%.

Title: N/A
Key Findings: Si-based PV is the most dominant technology with substantial advantages and is expected to maintain the best price competitiveness among all other potential PV technologies for the next decades. The traditional Al-BSF is gradually replaced by PERC and going to be outdated by 2026. The other c-Si based PV technologies including SHJ, TOPCon and IBC are expected to be mainstream in the latest 2/3 years due to their improved efficiency and reduced cost.
